title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0001
text: Which package contains the SortedSet interface?
explanation: The SortedSet interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0002
text: Which interface does SortedSet extend?
explanation: The SortedSet interface extends the Set interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0003
text: What is the main characteristic of a SortedSet?

options.text: Elements are stored in ascending order
Elements are stored in insertion order
Elements are stored in reverse order only

explanation: A SortedSet stores elements in ascending order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0004
text: Which of the following classes implements the SortedSet interface?
explanation: TreeSet is the main implementation of the SortedSet interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and duplicates?

options.text: SortedSet does not allow duplicate elements

explanation: SortedSet does not allow duplicate elements, just like Set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0006
text: Which of the following methods returns the first element in a SortedSet?
explanation: The first() method returns the first (lowest) element in the SortedSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods returns the last element in a SortedSet?
explanation: The last() method returns the last (highest) element in the SortedSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods returns a view of the portion of the set strictly less than a given element?
explanation: The headSet(E toElement) method returns a view of the portion of the set strictly less than the given element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods returns a view of the portion of the set greater than or equal to a given element?
explanation: The tailSet(E fromElement) method returns a view of the portion of the set greater than or equal to the given element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods returns a view of the portion of the set between two elements?
explanation: The subSet(E fromElement, E toElement) method returns a view of the portion of the set between two elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and null elements?

options.text: TreeSet does not allow null elements

explanation: TreeSet, the main implementation of SortedSet, does not allow null elements because it uses natural ordering.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and ordering?

options.text: SortedSet maintains elements in ascending order

explanation: SortedSet maintains elements in ascending order by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0013
text: Which of the following methods returns the comparator used to order the elements in a SortedSet?
explanation: The comparator() method returns the comparator used to order the elements in the set, or null if natural ordering is used.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and duplicates?
explanation: SortedSet does not allow duplicate elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and TreeSet?
explanation: TreeSet implements the SortedSet interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and comparator?

options.text: A custom Comparator can define the sorting order
Comparator cannot be used with SortedSet
Comparator is used only for duplicates

explanation: A custom Comparator can be provided to define the sorting order of elements in a SortedSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and natural ordering?

options.text: If no comparator is provided, natural ordering is used
Natural ordering is used only for duplicates

explanation: If no comparator is provided, SortedSet uses the natural ordering of its elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and null elements in TreeSet?

options.text: TreeSet does not allow null elements

explanation: TreeSet does not allow null elements because it uses natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and synchronization?

options.text: SortedSet is not synchronized by default

explanation: SortedSet is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedSortedSet().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0020
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a SortedSet?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedSortedSet() method returns a synchronized (thread-safe) sorted set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and immutability?

options.text: SortedSet can be made unmodifiable using Collections.unmodifiableSortedSet()

explanation: SortedSet can be made unmodifiable using the Collections.unmodifiableSortedSet() method.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and iteration order?

options.text: SortedSet iterates elements in ascending order
SortedSet iterates elements in insertion order
SortedSet iterates elements in reverse order only

explanation: SortedSet iterates elements in ascending order by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and descending order?

options.text: NavigableSet provides descendingSet() for reverse order

explanation: NavigableSet, a subinterface of SortedSet, provides descendingSet() for reverse order views.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and comparator() method?

options.text: comparator() returns null if natural ordering is used
comparator() throws an exception if no comparator is set

explanation: If natural ordering is used, comparator() returns null.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and subSet()?

options.text: subSet() returns a view between two elements

explanation: The subSet() method returns a view of the portion of the set between two elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and headSet()?

options.text: headSet() returns elements less than a given element
headSet() returns elements greater than a given element

explanation: The headSet() method returns a view of elements less than the specified element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and tailSet()?

options.text: tailSet() returns elements greater than or equal to a given element
tailSet() returns elements less than a given element

explanation: The tailSet() method returns a view of elements greater than or equal to the specified element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and TreeSet performance?

options.text: TreeSet provides O(log n) performance for basic operations

explanation: TreeSet provides O(log n) performance for add, remove, and contains operations.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most SortedSet implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most SortedSet implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and comparator usage?
explanation: Comparator defines custom sorting logic for elements in a SortedSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares sets based on elements only
equals() compares sets based on order
equals() compares sets based on references
equals() compares sets based on hash codes only

explanation: The equals() method compares sets based on their elements, not order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and hashCode()?

options.text: hashCode() is based on the elements in the set
hashCode() is based on insertion order

explanation: The hashCode() method of a SortedSet is based on the elements it contains.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and null elements in comparator-based sets?

options.text: Comparator must handle nulls explicitly if allowed

explanation: If nulls are allowed, the comparator must handle them explicitly to avoid exceptions.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and iteration?

options.text: Iterator traverses elements in sorted order
Iterator traverses elements in insertion order
Iterator traverses elements in reverse order

explanation: Iterator of a SortedSet traverses elements in sorted order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and size()?

options.text: size() returns the number of elements in the set
size() returns the capacity of the set

explanation: The size() method returns the number of elements in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and isEmpty()?

options.text: isEmpty() returns true if the set has no elements
isEmpty() returns false if the set has no elements
isEmpty() throws an exception if empty
isEmpty() returns the size of the set

explanation: The isEmpty() method returns true if the set contains no elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and contains()?

options.text: contains() checks if a specific element exists

explanation: The contains() method checks if a specific element exists in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and clear()?

options.text: clear() removes all elements from the set

explanation: The clear() method removes all elements from the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and add()?

options.text: add() inserts an element if not already present
add() throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: The add() method inserts an element if it is not already present in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and remove()?

options.text: remove() removes the specified element if present

explanation: The remove() method removes the specified element if it is present in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and retainAll()?

options.text: retainAll() keeps only elements present in another collection

explanation: The retainAll() method retains only the elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and removeAll()?

options.text: removeAll() removes all elements that are also in another collection

explanation: The removeAll() method removes all elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and containsAll()?

options.text: containsAll() checks if all elements of another collection are present

explanation: The containsAll() method checks if all elements of another collection are present in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and comparator-based sorting?
explanation: Comparator defines custom sorting logic for elements in a SortedSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and NavigableSet?

options.text: NavigableSet extends SortedSet with navigation methods
NavigableSet is a subtype of List

explanation: NavigableSet extends SortedSet and adds navigation methods like lower(), higher(), and descendingSet().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and TreeSet synchronization?

options.text: TreeSet is not synchronized by default

explanation: TreeSet is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedSortedSet().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and fail-fast iterators?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the set is modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and comparator chaining?

options.text: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria
Comparator chaining is used for synchronization

explanation: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria using methods like thenComparing().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about SortedSet and subSet() boundaries?

options.text: subSet() includes the lower bound and excludes the upper bound
subSet() includes only the upper bound

explanation: The subSet() method includes the lower bound and excludes the upper bound by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedSet - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the SortedSet interface?

options.text: A set that maintains elements in ascending order
A set that maintains insertion order
A set that stores elements randomly

explanation: The SortedSet interface represents a set that maintains elements in ascending order.
